title: The 5 Democrats Obama needs most on Iran
content:
Iran deal opponents need only four of 14 undecided Democratic senators to put President Barack Obama in the awkward spot of vetoing an attempt to scuttle a crowning foreign policy achievement . That ’ s set off a complicated race between hawks and the White House to win over an eclectic group of senators , each with his or her own particular concerns .
Any casual sports fan can attest that an almost .800 winning percentage is no easy feat , but that ’ s what Obama and his Hill allies need to pull off . And people on both sides of the rancorous Iran debate concede they have no idea whether Obama and his congressional allies can get there .
It ’ s hard to imagine a liberal stalwart like Sen. Jeff Merkley ( D-Ore. ) — who is formally undecided — coming out against the deal . But other senators are much tougher to read , even to people they speak with regularly . Among the enigmas are the top Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee , Maryland ’ s Ben Cardin , and Cory Booker , the star freshman from New Jersey caught between his loyalty to Obama and fierce opposition from Jewish groups .
“ Each has their own particular or unique approach , ” said Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin ( D-Ill. ) . “ We ’ re going after any Senate Democrat . ”
“ One of the reasons is that I ’ m confident we ’ re going to get 60 votes against the agreement , ” said former Sen. Joe Lieberman of Connecticut , an independent who allied with Democrats and is now a forceful opponent of the deal , “ is because Chuck Schumer is out there against it , ” referring to the New York senator and presumed next Democratic leader .
Here ’ s ███ ’ s look at the five key Democratic swing votes who will likely decide which side comes out on top :
If there ’ s a bellwether left in the Senate Democratic caucus , it ’ s the ranking member of the Foreign Relations Committee . A Jewish lawmaker from Baltimore , Cardin helped draft the law to give Congress a vote on the Iran deal with his triangulation between a White House that feared congressional oversight and Chairman Bob Corker ( R-Tenn. ) , now an opponent of the deal .
The Maryland Democrat is a more conciliatory figure than Sen. Robert Menendez ( D-N.J. ) , who lost his top spot on the panel after being indicted and is a strident critic of the president ’ s Iran policy . And though Cardin is more consistently supportive of the president ’ s foreign policy portfolio than Menendez , the Marylander has been irked by not being able to see a document detailing a deal between international inspectors and Iran .
Any Democrats waiting to see which way Cardin goes will have to sit tight : He ’ s not expected to announce a position until late next week at the earliest , and Corker says his friend and co-leader of the committee is truly undecided .
“ My conversations have not been to try to influence him and he knows that . We share the desire for the Senate to appropriately vote on this issue , ” Corker said in a phone interview . “ We ’ re both grown-ups . ”
Booker is getting buffeted on Iran probably more than any of the remaining undecided Democrats — including by his state ’ s voluble Republican governor and 2016 contender , Chris Christie .
At a news conference this week with Jewish leaders who oppose the pact , Christie called on all New Jersey lawmakers to oppose the Iran accord . But his real target was clear .
“ For Sen. Booker this morning , the people of your state , the people of this country and the people of the world are counting on you to be a strong , direct and powerful moral voice , ” Christie said at the event , held at the Chabad House at Rutgers University . “ To look your president in the eye — to look our president in the eye — and say , ‘ No , Mr. President . Not this time . ’ ”
A Booker spokeswoman said the senator will decide how to vote on the Iran agreement “ based upon what he believes is best for America ’ s national security regardless of political pressure , lobbying or theatrics . ”
Two other Democratic lawmakers from the New York region , Schumer and Menendez , are the party ’ s only senators so far on record opposed to the Iran deal .
The Delaware Democrat is showing a flair for drama as he mulls his decision . Coons has been one of the most publicly skeptical undecided Democrats and has spoken more with the White House on Iran than perhaps any other issue during his five-year run in the Senate .
He ’ s also not settling for a mere press release to make news , instead holding a public announcement on Tuesday at the University of Delaware .
Aside from Cardin , he ’ s the only undecided Democrat left on the Foreign Relations Committee . Obama spoke with Coons while the senator was on vacation earlier in August , and last week the senator met with constituent groups that included strong opponents of the deal , an aide said .
“ They ’ ve been very responsive to the extent I ’ ve got concerns and questions , ” Coons said of the White House before Congress left for its August recess . “ I ’ ve had opportunities to raise them and try to resolve them . ”
On Friday , his senior colleague , Sen. Tom Carper , endorsed the agreement as a “ good deal . ”
The sole vulnerable Democratic senator up for reelection in 2016 , Bennet faces an added layer of pressure that ’ s made him a prime target for both sides ahead of the Senate vote in September .
“ I have come to the conclusion that there is not a better deal available , ” he said at an energy event in Denver , though he added he ’ s still making up his mind . “ We are faced with a lot of bad choices now because we eliminated a lot of choices along the way . ”
J Street , a liberal pro-Israel group backing the deal , commissioned a poll earlier this month that showed 62 percent of Jewish voters in Colorado support the agreement — and called out Bennet for his noncommittal stance on the accord .
But he ’ s also been pounded with pressure campaigns from anti-deal groups such as Secure America Now , which has orchestrated thousands of calls to Bennet ’ s office urging the senator to oppose the agreement .
Bennet ’ s support for the deal would be “ a clear indication that he will follow Obama ’ s troubling direction on national security issues , ” said Andrea Bozek , a spokeswoman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee .
On one hand , Blumenthal is hearing from the ultimate Democratic hawk , Joe Lieberman . On the other , his fellow home-state senator , Democrat Chris Murphy , is an active participant on the pro-deal whip team .
Blumenthal has been a strong backer of congressional sanctions aimed at crippling Iran ’ s economy . But he ’ s keeping a low profile as Congress prepares to vote on the nuclear deal .
In an interview this summer , Blumenthal said he wouldn ’ t be swayed by the decision of Schumer or any of the Democratic boosters of the agreement . “ This issue is so consequential that the real guides here are going to be my personal conscience and conviction and all of the facts , ” he said .
The Connecticut lawmaker is up for reelection in 2016 and may not want to cause waves among many of his liberal constituents . But Lieberman , who spoke with the senator this month , isn ’ t letting him off easy .
“ I hope and pray he opposes the agreement , ” Lieberman said . “ This is the kind of agreement that Dick Blumenthal never would have negotiated . ”
Blumenthal also met with liberal activists from MoveOn and other advocacy groups on Wednesday . The organizations have been deploying demonstrators to the offices of undecided Democratic senators .
“ He raised the expectations of the people there , that he ’ s going to do the right thing , ” said Tom Swan , executive director of the Connecticut Citizen Action Group , who met with Blumenthal in Hartford .
Blumenthal also spoke with opponents of the Iran deal who were holding their own protests on Wednesday , an aide said .
content_original:
Iran deal opponents need only four of 14 undecided Democratic senators to put President Barack Obama in the awkward spot of vetoing an attempt to scuttle a crowning foreign policy achievement. That’s set off a complicated race between hawks and the White House to win over an eclectic group of senators, each with his or her own particular concerns.

Any casual sports fan can attest that an almost .800 winning percentage is no easy feat, but that’s what Obama and his Hill allies need to pull off. And people on both sides of the rancorous Iran debate concede they have no idea whether Obama and his congressional allies can get there.

Story Continued Below

It’s hard to imagine a liberal stalwart like Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) — who is formally undecided — coming out against the deal. But other senators are much tougher to read, even to people they speak with regularly. Among the enigmas are the top Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, Maryland’s Ben Cardin, and Cory Booker, the star freshman from New Jersey caught between his loyalty to Obama and fierce opposition from Jewish groups.

“Each has their own particular or unique approach,” said Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.). “We’re going after any Senate Democrat.”

“One of the reasons is that I’m confident we’re going to get 60 votes against the agreement,” said former Sen. Joe Lieberman of Connecticut, an independent who allied with Democrats and is now a forceful opponent of the deal, “is because Chuck Schumer is out there against it,” referring to the New York senator and presumed next Democratic leader.

Here’s POLITICO’s look at the five key Democratic swing votes who will likely decide which side comes out on top:

Ben Cardin of Maryland

If there’s a bellwether left in the Senate Democratic caucus, it’s the ranking member of the Foreign Relations Committee. A Jewish lawmaker from Baltimore, Cardin helped draft the law to give Congress a vote on the Iran deal with his triangulation between a White House that feared congressional oversight and Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), now an opponent of the deal.

The Maryland Democrat is a more conciliatory figure than Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.), who lost his top spot on the panel after being indicted and is a strident critic of the president’s Iran policy. And though Cardin is more consistently supportive of the president’s foreign policy portfolio than Menendez, the Marylander has been irked by not being able to see a document detailing a deal between international inspectors and Iran.

Any Democrats waiting to see which way Cardin goes will have to sit tight: He’s not expected to announce a position until late next week at the earliest, and Corker says his friend and co-leader of the committee is truly undecided.

“My conversations have not been to try to influence him and he knows that. We share the desire for the Senate to appropriately vote on this issue,” Corker said in a phone interview. “We’re both grown-ups.”

Cory Booker of New Jersey

Booker is getting buffeted on Iran probably more than any of the remaining undecided Democrats — including by his state’s voluble Republican governor and 2016 contender, Chris Christie.

At a news conference this week with Jewish leaders who oppose the pact, Christie called on all New Jersey lawmakers to oppose the Iran accord. But his real target was clear.

“For Sen. Booker this morning, the people of your state, the people of this country and the people of the world are counting on you to be a strong, direct and powerful moral voice,” Christie said at the event, held at the Chabad House at Rutgers University. “To look your president in the eye — to look our president in the eye — and say, ‘No, Mr. President. Not this time.’”

A Booker spokeswoman said the senator will decide how to vote on the Iran agreement “based upon what he believes is best for America’s national security regardless of political pressure, lobbying or theatrics.”

Two other Democratic lawmakers from the New York region, Schumer and Menendez, are the party’s only senators so far on record opposed to the Iran deal.

Chris Coons of Delaware

The Delaware Democrat is showing a flair for drama as he mulls his decision. Coons has been one of the most publicly skeptical undecided Democrats and has spoken more with the White House on Iran than perhaps any other issue during his five-year run in the Senate.

He’s also not settling for a mere press release to make news, instead holding a public announcement on Tuesday at the University of Delaware.

Aside from Cardin, he’s the only undecided Democrat left on the Foreign Relations Committee. Obama spoke with Coons while the senator was on vacation earlier in August, and last week the senator met with constituent groups that included strong opponents of the deal, an aide said.

“They’ve been very responsive to the extent I’ve got concerns and questions,” Coons said of the White House before Congress left for its August recess. “I’ve had opportunities to raise them and try to resolve them.”

On Friday, his senior colleague, Sen. Tom Carper, endorsed the agreement as a “good deal.”

Michael Bennet of Colorado

The sole vulnerable Democratic senator up for reelection in 2016, Bennet faces an added layer of pressure that’s made him a prime target for both sides ahead of the Senate vote in September.

The first-term senator hinted this week he’s leaning “yes.”

“I have come to the conclusion that there is not a better deal available,” he said at an energy event in Denver, though he added he’s still making up his mind. “We are faced with a lot of bad choices now because we eliminated a lot of choices along the way.”

J Street, a liberal pro-Israel group backing the deal, commissioned a poll earlier this month that showed 62 percent of Jewish voters in Colorado support the agreement — and called out Bennet for his noncommittal stance on the accord.

But he’s also been pounded with pressure campaigns from anti-deal groups such as Secure America Now, which has orchestrated thousands of calls to Bennet’s office urging the senator to oppose the agreement.

Bennet’s support for the deal would be “a clear indication that he will follow Obama’s troubling direction on national security issues,” said Andrea Bozek, a spokeswoman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut

On one hand, Blumenthal is hearing from the ultimate Democratic hawk, Joe Lieberman. On the other, his fellow home-state senator, Democrat Chris Murphy, is an active participant on the pro-deal whip team.

Blumenthal has been a strong backer of congressional sanctions aimed at crippling Iran’s economy. But he’s keeping a low profile as Congress prepares to vote on the nuclear deal.

In an interview this summer, Blumenthal said he wouldn’t be swayed by the decision of Schumer or any of the Democratic boosters of the agreement. “This issue is so consequential that the real guides here are going to be my personal conscience and conviction and all of the facts,” he said.

The Connecticut lawmaker is up for reelection in 2016 and may not want to cause waves among many of his liberal constituents. But Lieberman, who spoke with the senator this month, isn’t letting him off easy.

“I hope and pray he opposes the agreement,” Lieberman said. “This is the kind of agreement that Dick Blumenthal never would have negotiated.”

Blumenthal also met with liberal activists from MoveOn and other advocacy groups on Wednesday. The organizations have been deploying demonstrators to the offices of undecided Democratic senators.

“He raised the expectations of the people there, that he’s going to do the right thing,” said Tom Swan, executive director of the Connecticut Citizen Action Group, who met with Blumenthal in Hartford.

Blumenthal also spoke with opponents of the Iran deal who were holding their own protests on Wednesday, an aide said.

Manu Raju contributed to this report.
